  1. Introduction

    The thing I love C++ is that C++ gives your fully control over your machine.

    http://www.cplusplus.com

    C++ was created by Bjarne Stroustrup in 1979 as an extension of C language. The goal was to provide high-level features to C.

    In 1998, C++ was standardized by ISO, known as C++98.

    1. C++98
    2. C++03
    3. C++11
    4. C++14
    5. C++17

    In addition to the above ISO standard, there are also vendor specific standards, which are usually extension on the existed standard. For example, gun++11.

    Implmementation

    C++ compiler has different implementation, Clang, GCC, MSVC. For example, MacOS has a clang + LLVM implementation, where clang is the frontend that compile C++ to LLVM Intermediate Representation.

    1. Apple Clang

      In addition to support C++, Clang can also compile C, Objective-C and Swift to the LLVM IR.

    2. GUN Compiler Collection - GCC

      GCC supports C, C++, Objective-C, Fortran, Ada, Go. GCC supports serveral IRs.

  2. Compared with C

    1. Pointer
    2. Struct (But C++ does not need typedef.)
    3. Overload: same function name with different argument types. (the signature of a function includes its name and argument types.)

    Different

    1. static:

    Only C

    Only C++

    1. Inline
    2. Reference varaible
    3. Class:

  3. Primitive types and String

    1. Integer

      8 bits: (int8_t) char & unsigned char
      16 bits: (int16_t) short & unsigned short
      32 bits: (int32_t) int & unsigned int
      64 bits: (int64_t) long & unsigned long

      int & unsigned int: same bits with different signs will represent different number and have different behavior when doing the same operation.
      For example, adding two integers that overflow will set the CPU overflow flag. However, adding the same bits unsigned int will not.

      By default, an immediate integer number is interpreted as signed 32-bit int.

      #include <iostream>
int main()
{
    unsigned char uint8 = 93; // print as char. ]
    unsigned short uint16 = 93; // 93
    unsigned int uint32 = 0xf0000000; // 4026531840
    int32_t number = uint32; // -268435456
    int int32 = 0xf0000000; // -268435456
    unsigned long uint64 = 0xffffffffffffffff; // 18446744073709551615

    std::cout << uint8 << std::endl;
    std::cout << uint16 << std::endl;
    std::cout << uint32 << std::endl;
    std::cout << int32 << std::endl;
    std::cout << number << std::endl;
    std::cout << uint64 << std::endl;

    std::cout << 0x7fffffff + 0x7fffffff << std::endl; // -2
    std::cout << 0x7fffffffU + 0x7fffffffU << std::endl; // 4294967294
    return 0;
}

      AMD 64, little endian. construct a short 31206

                                  unsigned short value;
                            unsigned char * buf = (unsigned char *) &value;
                            std::cout << "0x" << std::hex <<  (unsigned long)&buf[0] << std::endl;
                            std::cout << "0x" << std::hex <<  (unsigned long)&buf[1] << std::endl;
                            buf[0] = 0xE6; // 0x7ffee256fb86
                            buf[1] = 0x79; // 0x7ffee256fb87
                        
                            std::cout << std::dec << value << std::endl; // 31206 = 0x97E6, little endian
                            return 0;

    2. Character

      char/unsigned char: A 8-bit byte represent ascii, it can also have number operation, e.g. +, -. C++ doesn't define "byte" itself.

      cout print unsgined char as ascii, instead of number.

      wchar_t

      wchar_t is a 2 or 4 bytes data type that encodes unicode. The actual size depends on compiler. (how to encode the unicode)

                                  wchar_t s = L'ç§¦'; // Unicode U+79E6, 31206
                            std::cout << s << std::endl; // 31206
                            std::cout << sizeof(s) << std::endl; // 4
                            return 0;

      cout cannot print the character, instead, it prints the unicode number.

    3. Float vs Double

      no unsigned float/double, float 4 bytes, double 8 bytes.

      IEEE 754

      IEEE 754 is the standard defined the representation of a singe/double precisonfloating number in memory.

                              [1] [2-9] [10-32]
                        sign,exponent,mantissa ; exponent bias = 127
                        [1] [2-12] [13-64]
                        sign,exponent,mantissa ; exponent bias = 1023

                        85.125 = 85 + 0.125 = 0b1010101 + 2^-3 = 0b1010101.001 = 0b1.010101001 * 2^6
                        exponent = 6 + 127 = 133 = 0b10000101, mantissa = 0b010101001
                        // exponent: add 127 offset so that we can represent negative exponent, e.g. 1 means 2^-126.

                        [0][10000101][010101001....]
                        01000010 10101010 01000000 00000000
                        42 aa 40 00
                    
          float f_85_125 = 85.125f; 
    //[0x00, 0x40, 0xaa, 0x42] -> little endian -> 
    // 0x42,0xaa,0x40,0x00 -> 0x42aa4000 -> [0]
    unsigned char * buffer = (unsigned char *) &f_85_125;
    std::cout << "0x" << std::hex <<  (int)buffer[0] << std::endl; // 0x00
    std::cout << "0x" << std::hex << (int)buffer[1] << std::endl; // 0x40
    std::cout << "0x" << std::hex << (int)buffer[2] << std::endl; // 0xaa
    std::cout << "0x" << std::hex << (int)buffer[3] << std::endl; // 0x42

    4. Boolean

      C doesn't define boolean. C++ boolean has two inhabitants, true and false, whose size is 1 byte (Java's boolean size depends on JVM)

      C++ cout cannot print the word of "true" or "false", instead, it prints 1 or 0 to represent true or false.

                              bool f = false, t = true;
                        std::cout << t << std::endl; // 1
                        std::cout << (f && t) << std::endl; // 0

      C++ boolean can be auto convert to int, and then perform arithmetic

                                  bool t = true;
                            int fn = t + t;
                            std::cout << fn << std::endl; // 2

  4. String

    C++ still has the C const string (c-string / string literal), but it also has a string class.

    1. string literal

      https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/string_literal

      string literal are not objects, they are const char[] declared in .code area. They are not objects and don't have member functions.

                              std::cout << "Where are you?" << std::endl; // this is a string literal;
                        std::string question = "Where are you?"; // question is a string object that convert the string literal to string object.

                        std::string << "qin" + " nan" << std::endl; // compile error since string literals are not string.

      unicode:

      auto concatenation: placing two string literal side by side concates another string literal at compile time.

    2. string class

      string in C++ is defined as class, and its mutable.

                              std::string txt = "qinnan";
                        .size(); // size_t const;
                        .length(); // same as above;
                        += // append to the original string
                        .push_back(char c);
                        [] // access, no error when out of range
                        .at(size_t pos); // return char &, a reference.

      Iteration of a string.

                                  for(std::string::iterator it = txt.begin(); it != txt.end(); it++){ // iterator is a inner type of string.
                                *it += 1; // mutable.
                            } 
                            for(auto it = txt.cbegin(); it != txt.cend(); it++){ // get a constant iterator type with auto inference.
                                std::cout << *it << ' ';
                            }
                            for (char & c: txt){
                                std::cout << c << ' '; // C++11
                            }

  5. C++ standard library

    C++ standard library is a collection of classes and functions specified in different header files, it's part of C++ ISO standard. These classes and functions are defined within the "std" namespace.

    GUN implementation is called libstdc++. This library is automatically linked to program.

    This library provides I/O, threading, collections, algorithm (sorting, hashing, math), memory, regex, localization, error handling.
